		<description><img width="680" height="473" src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/jan2018sillyteam.jpg?w=680" class="attachment-large size-large wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/jan2018sillyteam.jpg?w=680 680w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/jan2018sillyteam.jpg?w=1360 1360w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/jan2018sillyteam.jpg?w=150 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/jan2018sillyteam.jpg?w=300 300w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/jan2018sillyteam.jpg?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px" />&nbsp;In the latest chapter of GAFAM&#8217;s continuing bid to conquer online gaming, Microsoft has acquired PlayFab, which helps game developers launch their titles online more quickly with simplified back-end services. The startup will be integrated into Microsoft&#8217;s Azure gaming group. <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2018/01/29/microsoft-buys-cloud-gaming-startup-playfab-to-bolster-its-azure-gaming-platform/?ncid=rss">Read More</a><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TechCrunch/Gaming/~4/z-smTACSPqE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

		<description><img width="680" height="356" src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/facebook-game-streaming.png?w=680" class="attachment-large size-large wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/facebook-game-streaming.png?w=680 680w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/facebook-game-streaming.png?w=1360 1360w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/facebook-game-streaming.png?w=150 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/facebook-game-streaming.png?w=300 300w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2018/01/facebook-game-streaming.png?w=768 768w" sizes="(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px" />&nbsp;Facebook Live is launching monetization for video gameplay streamers, allowing users to tip creators a minimum of $3 via the desktop site. Right now, the contributor of the tips doesn&#8217;t get any special call-out or privileges, though Facebook tells me it&#8217;s considering different options for creators and gamers. <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2018/01/26/facebook-gamer-tipping/?ncid=rss">Read More</a><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TechCrunch/Gaming/~4/13pAjGiLxbk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
